awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Open Platform for Semantic Search
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will create and test a working semantic search platform using Search Maps to represent users' Search intent.  The effort will extend the ontology used in Phase I and build a complete system for generating high quality search results for typical searches. The recommendation architecture uses the similarity between Search Maps to introduce users to websites already discovered by others with similar Search Maps. 

If successful, this project will enable a new type of semantic search called User-driven Search, creating a new Search-enabled layer on top of the World Wide Web. As new way for users to manage, express, and resolve their Searches anywhere on the Internet, Search Maps create a new metaphor for helping users get more value out of the World Wide Web, no matter where they go. Coordinating queries and Search results provides immediate value as an enhanced Search tracking service. Allowing users to seamlessly send their Search Map to any provider would allow users to shortcut the traditional search and navigation paradigm at any and every website they visit.  The implications for e-commerce and enterprise search are significant.

por.por_cntn:
We developed an online semantic search system that helps people keep track of online activity and generates recommendations based on that activity.

Our research helps with online activities worth organizing, for example, when planning a vacation, researching a medical condition, or looking for a job. Both an automated activity logger and a digital scrapbook, our browser add-on stores related online activity in "Portable Contexts" on the user's hard drive. Individuals create and manage these contexts like any electronic document, putting just what they want in each and editing to suit their needs. If desired, the add-on can synchronize copies on our servers. In turn, we generate ongoing recommendations as people work.  These recommendations are based on the current context and displayed in a slim, horizontal toolbar in the browser. A predictive search and discovery architecture, our software leverages innate interest in organizing important activity to better understand what people are looking for.

This approach should be useful for capturing and organizing any coherent set of online activity. We believe it will help researchers, educators, and students when organizing online research as part of curriculum planning, background research, or even just secondary research for an essay.

Our most surprising result was the idea of using Portable Contexts for privacy-respecting service creation by any service provider on the World Wide Web. We realized that it would be useful to open up our platform and make it easy for other companies to help individuals by using the Portable Contexts created by our software.

Portable Contexts are a person's curated view into his or her current work; we see the user as the most appropriate authority for controlling that work.  With our approach (and further development), everyone could share their current context with service providers they trust. People could bring to service providers a rich representation of everything they've been doing for their current project, their categorizations, their queries, the notes and digital captures—the enhanced history that comprises the work of the moment.

Since Portable Contexts are documents on a hard drive, they provide an easily understandable locus for control and authority. The average person knows what it means to send a file as an attachment or upload an image to a website. With a file-based context management system, users would track those activities worth tracking and have an easy-to-understand way to share specific, curated information with online services they trust.

This approach offers an alternative solution to the current privacy challenges in the regulatory and policy conversations about behavioral tracking, third-party cookies, and Do-Not-Track. Currently, companies track individuals across the web with almost no control or visibility for the individual, for the purpose of guessing at what types of products and services the user is most likely to buy. While a Portable Context doesn't prevent that sort of tracking, it does provide a concrete, visible way for individuals to keep track of their own activity and in turn, provide this higher quality, curated, focused form of self-tracking to the service providers they trust most. By storing specific, related online activity in files on the hard drive, individuals create both a record for their own use over time, as well as a clearly bounded set of information that can explicitly be shared under specific terms with specific service providers. Inherently incorporating edits, categorizations, and notes of activities and discoveries anywhere online, Portable Contexts give service providers a more timely, focused, and complete foundation for personalization than they can gather from automated behavioral tracking at selected online sites.
